description:
From Middle English demonstracioun, from Old French demonstration, from Latin demonstrationem, from demonstrare (“show or explain”), from de- (“of or concerning”) + monstrare (“show”).
Morphologically demonstrate +‎ -ion

definitionGroups.group: The act of demonstrating; showing or explaining something.

entries.meaning: (prison slang) A prisoner's act of beating up another prisoner.
An event at which something will be demonstrated.
examples: I have to give a demonstration to the class tomorrow, and I'm ill-prepared.

entries.meaning: Expression of one's feelings by outward signs.
A public display of group opinion, such as a protest march.

examples: He read the proposition. […]  So he reads the demonstration of it, which referred him back to such a proposition,; which proposition he read.
